Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Microstructural Dynamics in Solvent-Responsive Complex Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL NO.: CTS-0547066
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS: VICTOR BREEDVELD
INSTITUTION: GEORGIA TECH.


CAREER: MICROSTRUCTURAL DYNAMICS IN SOLVENT-RESPONSIVE COMPLEX FLUIDS

The primary goal of the research is to develop and apply new experimental tools for real-time monitoring of the microstructure and rheology under variable solvent conditions (i.e. composition, ionic strength and pH). Such methods are currently unavailable and would have significant potential impact on improving the structure-property relations of complex fluids of practical importance. Examples include: drug delivery gels that must release their drug load within a limited time under narrowly defined pH conditions; consumer products, for which commercial success hinges on their mechanical properties and stability during ingestion (food) or application to salty skin (creams, shampoos); colloidal crystals, where the goal is to assemble ordered, defect-free arrays of colloids for optical and micro-separation applications. These are just a few cases where the functionality of complex fluids critically depends on our ability to predict and control their response to external stimuli, in particular structural rearrangements due to sudden changes in solvent composition. The lack of methodology to investigate these processes in detail is an important barrier in the development of new materials and is the main target of the proposed project. The research aims to provide experimental access to phenomena in complex fluids that are related to solvent-dependent molecular interactions by pursuing the following specific technological and scientific goals: (1) Development, optimization and calibration of new technology: dialysis cell for microscopy and microrheology; and (2) Application of the device in experimental studies that address important scientific issues in three areas: gel formation and break-up kinetics of solvent-induced hydrogels; dynamics of phase separation in polyelectrolyte-based hydrogels; and nucleation, growth and melting of charge-stabilized colloidal crystals. The work will have an immediate impact on the design and optimization of stimuli-responsive fluids in the pharmaceutical and consumer products industries by providing new quantitative tools to assess product performance and to guide product development. The program will also involve coordinated efforts to educate students at various levels of the educational system about 'complex fluids' and 'rheology'. In addition to graduate and undergraduate student research, the PI will initiate a new outreach effort for K-5 students that addresses specific standards of the Georgia K-5 science curriculum by using the 'supermarket science' of complex fluids; the outreach program is designed to ultimately impact a significant fraction of K-5 students in the metro-Atlanta school system, which includes large numbers of underrepresented minorities; the proposed approach offers an excellent opportunity to reach these students early on in their educational career.


Co-funded by the EHR Research on Learning and Education Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant was used to develop novel methods to study the microstructure and rheological properties of complex fluids that are sensitive to composition of the medium. Educational outreach was also supported in the form of a new elective course for undergraduate and graduate students, and an 8-lesson 5th grade Scienec module on "Supermarket Science". 

Soft materials in every day life often rely on changes in mechanical properties and microstructure in response to changes in composition. For example, gels for cell encapsulation are formed by exposing a biopolymer (alginate) solution to calcium ions. Guar gels that play a critical role in fracking processes in the oil and gas industry are formed by adding boron ions to the initially liquid-like solution, and after the fracking process is completed, these gels are broken down again by changing the pH value. Hydrogels for drug delivery are often triggered  to release their cargo of active compounds in response to well-defined changes in pH. Many food products also have mechanical properties ("thickness" and "stiffness") that are tuned by adjusting the composition.

Because many of the applications described above require control over the time-dependence of the changes in material properties, it is desirable to have techniques that can measure the evolution as a function of time. Prior to the start of this project, such techniques were not readily available. The development of a microdialysis cell for microrheology has made these measurements possible. By embedding small particles in a fluid and monitoring the random (Brownian) motion of these particles, it is possible to measure the viscosity ("thickness") and elasticity ("stiffness") of the fluid: thicker and stiffer fluids suppress the particle motion. By combining such microrheology with a clever sample chamber design that enables free exchange of small molecules between the sample and an adjacent reservoir, we have been able to change the sample composition of the fluids, while simultaneously measuring the motion of the tracer particles.

This new device has been used to measure the solvent-responsiveness of several types of complex fluids: alginate gel formation and break-down through the addition/removal of calcium ions, the expansion and collapse of polymer molecules upon addition of different salts, the swelling and deswelling of colloidal microgel particles due to pH changes, and the binding of proteins with biomolecules, among other studies. Several of these projects were carried out with external collaborators in academia and industry who had a need for our unique technique. As a result, this grant from NSF has made it possible to develop a new paradigm for researchers, treating the solvent composition in complex fluids as a parameter that can be varied druing measurements, instead of having to keep it constant over the course of an experiment.

The design, characterization and applications of the microdialysis cell have been documented in journal articles and presented at scientific meetings.

In addition to these efforts, an 8-lesson module on "Supermarket Science" was developed for the 5th-grade Science curriculum. The lesson material provides a strong connection between fundamental scientific concepts and products that students encounter in everyday life. This was carried out in close collaboration with an elemtary school teacher, who provided the classroom expertise and tested the lesson plans. The "Supermarket Science" module has been presented at teacher conferences and workshops. The material has been implemented by several teachers in Georgia and other Southeastern states with very enthusiastic responses from the students.
